Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Novel Form of Distributed Electric Propulsion for UAVs and Air Mobility
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to advance the capability for both unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and air taxis to operate in urban environments. The form factor of this propulsion technology will allow air vehicles to maneuver, land, and park in tight spaces and to reduce or eliminate the risk of propeller contact injuries. These new capabilities will allow unmanned aerial vehicles and air taxis to operate in dense urban environments and in closer proximity to human beings without risk of injury or collision with the urban environment. In turn, this will accelerate applications such as autonomous package delivery, where UAVs are expected to operate autonomously around unpredictable humans, as well as air taxis, with inherent challenges in tight maneuvering and proximity to waiting passengers. Furthermore, these manufacturing techniques may find other applications in fields such as wearable and implanted hybrid electronic systems. <br/><br/>This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will advance the state of the art in unmanned aerial vehicle and manned air vehicle capabilities. The proposed research will develop a novel propulsion solution that can be built to form factors unachievable with current technology. These form factors can be designed to both eliminate the possibility of propeller contact injuries to human beings and allow a significantly higher degree of maneuverability in very close quarters. The implementation of this solution will require new innovations in the manufacture of flexible hybrid electronics (FHE), combining flexible substrates with support electronics. This project will evaluate the technical feasibility of this proposed approach through the construction of a prototype device using flexible hybrid electronics manufacturing techniques. This project will then conduct verification and validation tests in environments relevant to the missions envisioned for unmanned aerial vehicles and other urban air mobility systems.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project demonstrated a novel new manufacturing technique and solved several unique engineering problems specific to this technology.  Specifically we had to overcome and create novel methods that combined electronics manufacturing, nanotechnology, and aerospace technology.  The demonstration system that we constructed is able to showcase these innovations in a compelling and understandable manner.  Most importantly, this project significantly de-risked an emerging high-potential, high-risk technology.

The demonstration vehicle constructed in this project will be used as a testbed for additional technology enhancements and performance improvements.  We expect that the findings that we learn from this demonstration vehicle will allow us to further develop this technology and meet the needs of commercial users.

The broader impacts of this project will positively affect manufacturing in the future and will enable new advances in both the electronics and aerospace industries.  It is likely that the advances discovered and created as part of this project will have both an immediate impact and will be continue to be built upon to solve future challenges, particularly in advanced manufacturing.  

This technology platform has the potential both to preserve manufacturing jobs within the United States as well as create new opportunities for manufacturing and technical fields not possible with current technology.


Last Modified: 03/31/2022
Modified by: Andrew P Dickens
